concept.title: Security controls for Couchbase Server
concept.shortdesc: Couchbase Server provides several security controls including authentication, authorization, auditing and encryption to secure your database and applications.

conbody.p: By using the Couchbase security controls, and best practices [Link], you can secure your Couchbase deployment in production.

section.title: Authentication
section.p: Before applications connect to the server, they need to identify themselves to Couchbase. Couchbase Server supports SASL and non-SASL buckets to store your data. To verify the identity of administrators and applications, Couchbase Server supports a challenge-response authentication mechanism (CRAM) based on the HMAC-MD5 algorithm. Additionally, the enterprise version of Couchbase Server supports LDAP authentication for administrators connecting to through the administrative web console. See for more details.

section.title: Authorization for administrators and applications
section.p: Authorization determines what privileges a principal has to resources and operations. For SASL buckets, knowing the password controls whether or not applications have access to the bucket. Administrators have full control over the Couchbase cluster. By setting up a read-only administrator in Couchbase, you can configure an administrator to have a read-only view of the cluster information without access to the data. Using Couchbase enterprise and LDAP, you can configure multiple administrators and read-only administrators. See for more details.

section.title: Auditing
section.p: Auditing describes who, did, what, when and how. With auditing enabled, auditors can monitor the actions carried out by administrators in the Couchbase cluster. Auditing is essential to comply with several regulatory compliance regulations and internal security policies. To read more about auditing, see .

section.title: Encryption
section.p: By using encryption at multiple levels, you can protect your sensitive data in Couchbase

dlentry.dt: Data encryption at the application layer
dlentry.dd: Data model employed by Couchbase Server allows you to store both JSON documents as well as binary data (for example an encrypted blob). To encrypt a document or document attributes, you can use a commercial solution such as the Vormetric Data Security Platform, without the complexity and risk of implementing an in-house encryption and key management solution.

Using SSL, clients can securely communicate with the server to access data. Administrators can also securely connect to the admin console and manage the cluster through the browser, even over a public network. Couchbase also provides encryption over SSL for cross data-center replication (XDCR) traffic. You can read more about SSL in Couchbase here [Link]

You can encrypt sensitive data on disk to ensure that only authorized processes can get access. There are third-party libraries available that can be used to encrypt data in Couchbase transparently, without any application changes. For example:
Vormetric Data Security Platform The Vormetric Data Security Platform provides disk and file-level encryption in addition to application level encryption.
LUKS based encryption on Linux Various Linux distributions ship with LUKS and provide full disk encryption options. For example, here’s how to get started with Ubuntu’s full-disk encryption, courtesy of Ubuntu’s community help documentation.
Bitlocker Drive Encryption Bitlocker Drive Encryption is a feature available on Windows Server 2008 and 2012 that provides disk encryption. Properly configured disk encryption, when used alongside good security best practices, can help ensure compliance with standards, including PCI-DSS, and HIPAA.

Security best practices provide a layered approach to security through a set of guidelines that you can follow at the network layer, database layer, application layer, and when running Couchbase Server in cloud environments. To read more about Couchbase Server's security best practices, see .
